elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increased research attention in photocatalysis due to their great potential in light harvest and conversion. However, the organic transformations as photocatalyzed by MOFs under mild conditions yet remain a challenge. Herein, three bipyridyl-containing cadmium–organic frameworks Cd­(dcbpy) (dcbpy = 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate), Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; bpy = 2,2′-bipyridyl), and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) (2Me-bpy = 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridyl) were synthesized for the first time. The bpy-containing Cd-MOFs have strong light harvest abilities and suitable photocatalysis energy potentials, making them highly active and selective for the photo-oxidation of benzylamine to N-benzylbenzaldimine under mild conditions, i.e., using atmospheric air as oxidant, at room temperature, and in the absence of any photosensitizer or cocatalyst. It provides an efficient, economical, and green way for the direct oxidation of amines to produce imines.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increased research attention in photocatalysis due to their great potential in light harvest and conversion. However, the organic transformations as photocatalyzed by MOFs under mild conditions yet remain a challenge. Herein, three bipyridyl-containing cadmium-organic frameworks Cd(dcbpy) (dcbpy = 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylate), Cd(bdc)(bpy) (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; bpy = 2,2'-bipyridyl), and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) (2Me-bpy = 4,4'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridyl) were synthesized for the first time. The bpy-containing Cd-MOFs have strong light harvest abilities and suitable photocatalysis energy potentials, making them highly active and selective for the photo-oxidation of benzylamine to N-benzylbenzaldimine under mild conditions, i.e., using atmospheric air as oxidant, at room temperature, and in the absence of any photosensitizer or cocatalyst. It provides an efficient, economical, and green way for the direct oxidation of amines to produce imines.

elements.content: Imines are very important intermediates for the synthesis of dyes, pharmaceutically and biologically active compounds, and fine chemicals. The traditional method for imine synthesis is the condensation of amines with carbonyl compounds, during which the unstable aldehydes, dehydrating agents, and Lewis acid catalysts are usually requisite. Alternatively, the direct synthesis of imines (i.e., self-coupling of primary amines) through an oxidative process has attracted much attention, owing to the advantages of readily available starting materials, reduced energy consumption, and simplified procedures, etc. In particular, to utilize sunlight as the energy force for direct imine synthesis is a greener way. Various kinds of photocatalysts have been used for the direct oxidation of amines to corresponding imines, e.g., TiO2, Nb2O5, WO3, and the binary or ternary systems of Au@ZrO2, Pd@ZrO2, Au–Pd@ZrO2, and Ag/AgI/titanate. Even with the precious metal combination, the performances of these inorganic semiconductors for imine production are still limited.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Imines are very important intermediates for the synthesis of dyes, pharmaceutically and biologically active compounds, and fine chemicals. The traditional method for imine synthesis is the condensation of amines with carbonyl compounds, during which the unstable aldehydes, dehydrating agents, and Lewis acid catalysts are usually requisite. Alternatively, the direct synthesis of imines (i.e., self-coupling of primary amines) through an oxidative process has attracted much attention, owing to the advantages of readily available starting materials, reduced energy consumption, and simplified procedures, etc. In particular, to utilize sunlight as the energy force for direct imine synthesis is a greener way. Various kinds of photocatalysts have been used for the direct oxidation of amines to corresponding imines, e.g., TiO2, Nb2O5, WO3, and the binary or ternary systems of Au@ZrO2, Pd@ZrO2, Au-Pd@ZrO2, and Ag/AgI/titanate. Even with the precious metal combination, the performances of these inorganic semiconductors for imine production are still limited.

elements.content: In recent years, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been regarded as one of the most important classes of materials, owing to their potential applications in diverse fields such as gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, luminescence, biomedicine, and heterogeneous catalysis. Composed of metal ions/clusters and organic linkers, MOFs provide light-harvesting platforms and catalytic centers for various kinds of photocatalytic reactions, e.g., organic transformation, water splitting, and CO2 reduction, etc. However, the utilization of MOF as photocatalyst for oxidation of amines has not been reported until 2015. Li and co-workers found for the first time that NH2-MIL-125 (Ti) exhibits photocatalytic activity for the aerobic selective oxidation of amines to imines, of which the performance still has a large space to improve. Duan and co-workers synthesized a metal–organic polymer of Zn-PDI (PDI = perylene diimide) for the improved oxidation of benzylamines. Zhang et al. and Jiang et al. used porphyrinic MOFs for the aerobic photo-oxidative coupling of amines under ambient conditions. Despite the greatly improved efficiency, these photoactive MOFs suffer from either expensive organic linkers or complex synthesis procedure. It is urgent to develop highly active, low-cost, and versatile MOF photocatalysts to make the imine production more practical and efficient.
elements.clean_text: In recent years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been regarded as one of the most important classes of materials, owing to their potential applications in diverse fields such as gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, luminescence, biomedicine, and heterogeneous catalysis. Composed of metal ions/clusters and organic linkers, MOFs provide light-harvesting platforms and catalytic centers for various kinds of photocatalytic reactions, e.g., organic transformation, water splitting, and CO2 reduction, etc. However, the utilization of MOF as photocatalyst for oxidation of amines has not been reported until 2015. Li and co-workers found for the first time that NH2-MIL-125 (Ti) exhibits photocatalytic activity for the aerobic selective oxidation of amines to imines, of which the performance still has a large space to improve. Duan and co-workers synthesized a metal-organic polymer of Zn-PDI (PDI = perylene diimide) for the improved oxidation of benzylamines. Zhang et al. and Jiang et al. used porphyrinic MOFs for the aerobic photo-oxidative coupling of amines under ambient conditions. Despite the greatly improved efficiency, these photoactive MOFs suffer from either expensive organic linkers or complex synthesis procedure. It is urgent to develop highly active, low-cost, and versatile MOF photocatalysts to make the imine production more practical and efficient.

elements.content: Herein, we design a new kind of light self-sensitized bipyridyl (bpy)-containing Cd-MOFs for the photo-oxidation of amines to imines at air atmosphere and room temperature (). The aim of utilizing bpy-containing ligand is that it is electron rich and sensitive to light, making it active in many photocatalysis systems. Moreover, the bpy-containing linkers are much cheaper and more readily available than the porphyrinic or perylene diimide linkers used in the literature. The combination of the light-sensitive bpy-containing ligands and Cd­(II) ions would endow the corresponding MOFs strong light-harvesting abilities and suitable photocatalysis energy potentials. Thus, the bpy-containing Cd-MOFs are expected to exhibit high performances for photocatalytic oxidation of benzylamines at mild conditions.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we design a new kind of light self-sensitized bipyridyl (bpy)-containing Cd-MOFs for the photo-oxidation of amines to imines at air atmosphere and room temperature (). The aim of utilizing bpy-containing ligand is that it is electron rich and sensitive to light, making it active in many photocatalysis systems. Moreover, the bpy-containing linkers are much cheaper and more readily available than the porphyrinic or perylene diimide linkers used in the literature. The combination of the light-sensitive bpy-containing ligands and Cd(II) ions would endow the corresponding MOFs strong light-harvesting abilities and suitable photocatalysis energy potentials. Thus, the bpy-containing Cd-MOFs are expected to exhibit high performances for photocatalytic oxidation of benzylamines at mild conditions.

elements.content: The bpy-containing Cd-MOFs, Cd­(dcbpy), Cd­(bdc)­(bpy), and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) were synthesized by a simple route shown in , where dcbpy, bdc, and 2Me-bpy represent 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridyl, respectively. Typically, the desired amounts of CdI2 and the bpy-containing ligands were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), followed by the addition of a certain amount of triethylamine (TEA). After a solvothermal route at 120 °C for 24 h under stirring, the product was obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The bpy-containing Cd-MOFs, Cd(dcbpy), Cd(bdc)(bpy), and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) were synthesized by a simple route shown in , where dcbpy, bdc, and 2Me-bpy represent 2,2'-bipyridine-5,5'-dicarboxylate, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and 4,4'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridyl, respectively. Typically, the desired amounts of CdI2 and the bpy-containing ligands were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), followed by the addition of a certain amount of triethylamine (TEA). After a solvothermal route at 120 °C for 24 h under stirring, the product was obtained.

elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic Illustration for the Synthesis of Cd(dcbpy), Cd(bdc)(bpy), and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy), Respectively

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) reveals that the three products are well crystallized ( Figure S1) and their crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique (). The cell parameters and structure refinement details are given in . Cd­(dcbpy) possesses a three-dimensional (3D) network and crystallizes in Fddd space group (a,b). The smallest diameter of the pores was measured to be 6.26 Å. As shown in a, Cd­(dcbpy) is a binuclear complex and each Cd­(II) ion coordinates with two N atoms from one ligand dcbpy2– and four O atoms from four dcbpy2– ligands, respectively. The two Cd­(II) ions are connected by four O–C–O bridges and have a distance of 3.494 Å (). The binuclear Cd­(II) ions form two planes with the coordinated ligands with a plane angle of 82.2°. Different from Cd­(dcbpy), Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) is mononuclear and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. Cd­(II) ions are bridged by bdc2– ligands to form zigzag chains (c). Beside the four coordinated O atoms from bdc2–, each Cd­(II) ion coordinates with two N atoms from one bpy (). The chains interact through π···π stacking with a distance 3.50 Å to form an extended 3D structure (d and ). The smallest diameter of the pores was measured to be 5.66 Å. Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. It is a binuclear complex, and each Cd­(II) ion is seven coordinated, with five O atoms and two N atoms (e). The distance between the binuclear Cd atoms is 3.737 Å (). The extended structure is in a form of two-layer plane with bdc2– as bridge, and the thickness is 3.15 Å. As shown in f, the two-layer planes in the red dash rectangle form an extended 3D structure through π···π stacking. The smallest diameter of the pores was measured to be 5.36 Å. The simulated XRD patterns from single-crystal XRD data of the three Cd-MOFs coincide well with the experimental powder XRD patterns (). Moreover, Fourier transformed infrared spectra of the three Cd-MOFs prove the coordination of organic ligands with Cd­(II) ions (). Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that Cd­(dcbpy), Cd­(bdc)­(bpy), and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) can remain stable upon heating to 400, 250, and 365 °C, respectively (). Evidently, Cd­(dcbpy) has the highest thermal stability among these three Cd-MOFs, which is easily understood in that the complete coordination bonds between Cd­(II) ions and dcbpy2– in Cd­(dcbpy) are stronger than the interactions in Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) and Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) for the existence of partial π···π stacking interactions.
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) reveals that the three products are well crystallized ( Figure S1) and their crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction technique (). The cell parameters and structure refinement details are given in . Cd(dcbpy) possesses a three-dimensional (3D) network and crystallizes in Fddd space group (a,b). The smallest diameter of the pores was measured to be 6.26 Å. As shown in a, Cd(dcbpy) is a binuclear complex and each Cd(II) ion coordinates with two N atoms from one ligand dcbpy2- and four O atoms from four dcbpy2- ligands, respectively. The two Cd(II) ions are connected by four O-C-O bridges and have a distance of 3.494 Å (). The binuclear Cd(II) ions form two planes with the coordinated ligands with a plane angle of 82.2°. Different from Cd(dcbpy), Cd(bdc)(bpy) is mononuclear and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. Cd(II) ions are bridged by bdc2- ligands to form zigzag chains (c). Beside the four coordinated O atoms from bdc2-, each Cd(II) ion coordinates with two N atoms from one bpy (). The chains interact through π⋅⋅⋅π stacking with a distance 3.50 Å to form an extended 3D structure (d and ). The smallest diameter of the pores was measured to be 5.66 Å. Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. It is a binuclear complex, and each Cd(II) ion is seven coordinated, with five O atoms and two N atoms (e). The distance between the binuclear Cd atoms is 3.737 Å (). The extended structure is in a form of two-layer plane with bdc2- as bridge, and the thickness is 3.15 Å. As shown in f, the two-layer planes in the red dash rectangle form an extended 3D structure through π⋅⋅⋅π stacking. The smallest diameter of the pores was measured to be 5.36 Å. The simulated XRD patterns from single-crystal XRD data of the three Cd-MOFs coincide well with the experimental powder XRD patterns (). Moreover, Fourier transformed infrared spectra of the three Cd-MOFs prove the coordination of organic ligands with Cd(II) ions (). Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that Cd(dcbpy), Cd(bdc)(bpy), and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) can remain stable upon heating to 400, 250, and 365 °C, respectively (). Evidently, Cd(dcbpy) has the highest thermal stability among these three Cd-MOFs, which is easily understood in that the complete coordination bonds between Cd(II) ions and dcbpy2- in Cd(dcbpy) are stronger than the interactions in Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) and Cd(bdc)(bpy) for the existence of partial π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions.

elements.content: Crystal structures of Cd­(dcbpy) (a, b), Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) (c, d), and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) (e, f). Legend: violet for Cd, red for O, blue for N, and gray for C. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of Cd(dcbpy) (a, b), Cd(bdc)(bpy) (c, d), and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) (e, f). Legend: violet for Cd, red for O, blue for N, and gray for C. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The as-synthesized Cd-MOFs were used as photocatalysts for the oxidation of benzylamine reaction at mild conditions, i.e., air atomosphere and 25 °C, and the results are listed in . As catalyzed by Cd­(dcbpy), the conversion of benzylamine increases with time and is almost completely converted into N-benzylbenzaldimine within 7 h (entries 1–7). The turnover frequency (TOF) is 3398 μmol·g–1·h–1 (entry 7). A comparison of the catalytic performance of the as-synthesized Cd­(dcbpy) with the reported photocatalysts is listed in . Outstandingly, Cd­(dcbpy) exhibits much higher activity than the inorganic semiconductors (e.g., TiO2, Nb2O5, and WO3 ) and even the noble metal doped semiconductors under similar conditions. As compared with other MOF photocatalysts, the catalytic performance of Cd­(dcbpy) is much better than that of NH2-MIL-125 (Ti) and comparable to those of the porphyrinic and perylene diimide MOFs. For comparison, the reaction catalyzed by Cd­(dcbpy) in dark condition was carried out. No products were obtained even as the reaction time was prolonged to 24 h, confirming that the reaction is driven by light (entry 8). In addition, pure N2 atmosphere was used to replace air atmosphere, while the other experimental conditions were the same as those for entries 1–7. After light irradiation for 24 h, the conversion of benzylamine was undetected (entry 9), which proves that O2 in air plays a role of oxidant in the reaction. Moreover, the reaction in the absence of Cd­(dcbpy) under light irradiation and air atmosphere was carried out. There was no product as the reaction time was 24 h, proving that the reaction is catalyzed by Cd­(dcbpy). The Cd­(dcbpy) catalyst was reused for three catalytic cycles, and the reaction time for each cycle was 6 h. There is almost no activity loss (entries 10–12), and the catalyst well maintains its crystal structure ().
elements.clean_text: The as-synthesized Cd-MOFs were used as photocatalysts for the oxidation of benzylamine reaction at mild conditions, i.e., air atomosphere and 25 °C, and the results are listed in . As catalyzed by Cd(dcbpy), the conversion of benzylamine increases with time and is almost completely converted into N-benzylbenzaldimine within 7 h (entries 1-7). The turnover frequency (TOF) is 3398 μmol⋅g-1⋅h-1 (entry 7). A comparison of the catalytic performance of the as-synthesized Cd(dcbpy) with the reported photocatalysts is listed in . Outstandingly, Cd(dcbpy) exhibits much higher activity than the inorganic semiconductors (e.g., TiO2, Nb2O5, and WO3 ) and even the noble metal doped semiconductors under similar conditions. As compared with other MOF photocatalysts, the catalytic performance of Cd(dcbpy) is much better than that of NH2-MIL-125 (Ti) and comparable to those of the porphyrinic and perylene diimide MOFs. For comparison, the reaction catalyzed by Cd(dcbpy) in dark condition was carried out. No products were obtained even as the reaction time was prolonged to 24 h, confirming that the reaction is driven by light (entry 8). In addition, pure N2 atmosphere was used to replace air atmosphere, while the other experimental conditions were the same as those for entries 1-7. After light irradiation for 24 h, the conversion of benzylamine was undetected (entry 9), which proves that O2 in air plays a role of oxidant in the reaction. Moreover, the reaction in the absence of Cd(dcbpy) under light irradiation and air atmosphere was carried out. There was no product as the reaction time was 24 h, proving that the reaction is catalyzed by Cd(dcbpy). The Cd(dcbpy) catalyst was reused for three catalytic cycles, and the reaction time for each cycle was 6 h. There is almost no activity loss (entries 10-12), and the catalyst well maintains its crystal structure ().

elements.content:
Catalytic Activity of Cd­(dcbpy),<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> Cd­(bdc)­(bpy),<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy)<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> for Amine Oxidation Reaction entry R in reactant time/h conversion/% selectivity/% TOF/(μmol·g–1·h–1) 1 H 1 20.8 >99 4992 2 H 2 41.8 >99 5016 3 H 3 61.2 >99 4896 4 H 4 78.4 >99 4704 5 H 5 89.9 >99 4315 6 H 6 98.1 >99 3924 7 H 7 99.1 >99 3398 8 H 24 0 - 0 9 H 24 0 - 0 10 H 6 92.3 >99 3692 11 H 6 88.9 >99 3556 12 H 6 89.4 >99 3576 13 CH3 6 68.7 >99 2748 14 OCH3 6 61.5 >99 2460 15 Cl 6 67.8 >99 2712 16 OCF3 6 52.8 >99 2112 17 H 2 9.84 >99 1181 18 H 4 18.9 >99 1134 19 H 7 35.5 >99 1217 20 H 2 4.4 >99 528 21 H 4 9.3 >99 558 22 H 7 16.2 >99 555

Reaction conditions: 25 °C, air, 0.48 mmol amine, 10 mg of catalyst, 5 mL of DMF, 300 W Xe lamp.

In dark, the other conditions being the same as those of footnote .

N2 atmosphere, the other conditions being the same as those of footnote .

The photocatalytic activities of Cd­(dcbpy) for the oxidations of other benzylamine derivatives were explored, the experimental conditions being the same as those above. As listed in entries 13–16, the conversions of benzylamines with -CH3, -OCH3, -Cl, and -OCF3 derivatives are 68.7%, 61.5%, 67.8%, and 52.8% at 6 h, respectively. All of the selectivities to their respective coupled imines are >99%. The corresponding TOF values for the first three amines are 2748, 2460, and 2712 μmol·g–1·h–1, which are higher than those of the reported Nb2O5 with 1238, 1031, and 544 μmol·g–1·h–1, respectively. By combination with the result of entry 6, it is evident that the substitution of a larger group (e.g., -CH3, -OCH3, -Cl, or -OCF3) for the para-position hydrogen results in the decreased reaction rate. It can be attributed to the steric effect of larger groups that hinder the entering of larger reactant molecules into the MOF channel.
elements.clean_text: The photocatalytic activities of Cd(dcbpy) for the oxidations of other benzylamine derivatives were explored, the experimental conditions being the same as those above. As listed in entries 13-16, the conversions of benzylamines with -CH3, -OCH3, -Cl, and -OCF3 derivatives are 68.7%, 61.5%, 67.8%, and 52.8% at 6 h, respectively. All of the selectivities to their respective coupled imines are >99%. The corresponding TOF values for the first three amines are 2748, 2460, and 2712 μmol⋅g-1⋅h-1, which are higher than those of the reported Nb2O5 with 1238, 1031, and 544 μmol⋅g-1⋅h-1, respectively. By combination with the result of entry 6, it is evident that the substitution of a larger group (e.g., -CH3, -OCH3, -Cl, or -OCF3) for the para-position hydrogen results in the decreased reaction rate. It can be attributed to the steric effect of larger groups that hinder the entering of larger reactant molecules into the MOF channel.

elements.content: The catalytic performances of the other two Cd-MOFs for the photo-oxidation reaction were investigated. As shown in (entries 17–22), both of them can catalyze the benzylamine oxidation at mild conditions with selectivities to N-benzylbenzaldimine of >99%. The TOF values at 7 h are 1217 and 555 μmol·g–1·h–1 for Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy), respectively. By combination with the above results (entries 2, 4, and 7), it is evident that Cd­(dcbpy) presents the best photocatalytic performance among these three catalysts for the benzylamine oxidation reaction.
elements.clean_text: The catalytic performances of the other two Cd-MOFs for the photo-oxidation reaction were investigated. As shown in  (entries 17-22), both of them can catalyze the benzylamine oxidation at mild conditions with selectivities to N-benzylbenzaldimine of >99%. The TOF values at 7 h are 1217 and 555 μmol⋅g-1⋅h-1 for Cd(bdc)(bpy) and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy), respectively. By combination with the above results (entries 2, 4, and 7), it is evident that Cd(dcbpy) presents the best photocatalytic performance among these three catalysts for the benzylamine oxidation reaction.

elements.content: To get information on the underlying mechanism for the catalytic performances of the as-synthesized Cd-MOFs, their optical properties and electronic band structures were analyzed by UV–vis absorption spectra and Mott–Schottky plots. As shown in a, the absorption of Cd­(dcbpy) is red-shifted as compared with those of Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) and Cd­(bdc)­(bpy). The optical band gaps of the three Cd-MOFs were estimated from Tauc plots to be 3.48, 3.59, and 3.75 eV for Cd­(dcbpy), Cd­(bdc)­(bpy), and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy), respectively. Mott–Schottky measurements were conducted at the frequencies of 500 and 1500 Hz to elucidate their positions of conduction band (CB) edges (). The flat band positions as determined are −1.10, −0.91, and −1.20 V vs Ag/AgCl for Cd­(dcbpy), Cd­(bdc)­(bpy), and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy), respectively. The tops of the corresponding valence band (VB) edges were then calculated to be 2.38, 2.68, and 2.55 V vs Ag/AgCl (b), respectively. Such energy-band structures in the three Cd-MOFs make them theoretically feasible for O2 photoreduction (−0.82 V vs Ag/AgCl) and benzylamine oxidation (1.08 V vs Ag/AgCl).
elements.clean_text: To get information on the underlying mechanism for the catalytic performances of the as-synthesized Cd-MOFs, their optical properties and electronic band structures were analyzed by UV-vis absorption spectra and Mott-Schottky plots. As shown in a, the absorption of Cd(dcbpy) is red-shifted as compared with those of Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) and Cd(bdc)(bpy). The optical band gaps of the three Cd-MOFs were estimated from Tauc plots to be 3.48, 3.59, and 3.75 eV for Cd(dcbpy), Cd(bdc)(bpy), and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy), respectively. Mott-Schottky measurements were conducted at the frequencies of 500 and 1500 Hz to elucidate their positions of conduction band (CB) edges (). The flat band positions as determined are -1.10, -0.91, and -1.20 V vs Ag/AgCl for Cd(dcbpy), Cd(bdc)(bpy), and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy), respectively. The tops of the corresponding valence band (VB) edges were then calculated to be 2.38, 2.68, and 2.55 V vs Ag/AgCl (b), respectively. Such energy-band structures in the three Cd-MOFs make them theoretically feasible for O2 photoreduction (-0.82 V vs Ag/AgCl) and benzylamine oxidation (1.08 V vs Ag/AgCl).

elements.content: (a) UV–vis absorption spectra and band gap energies (inset). (b) Energy-band diagrams of the three Cd-MOFs. (c) Steady-state PL spectra (270 nm excitation at room temperature). (d) Transient photocurrent response under light irradiation. Legend: black, Cd­(dcbpy); red, Cd­(bdc)­(bpy); blue, Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) UV-vis absorption spectra and band gap energies (inset). (b) Energy-band diagrams of the three Cd-MOFs. (c) Steady-state PL spectra (270 nm excitation at room temperature). (d) Transient photocurrent response under light irradiation. Legend: black, Cd(dcbpy); red, Cd(bdc)(bpy); blue, Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy).

elements.content: Further, the separation efficiency and transfer behavior of photoinduced charges in the photocatalysts, which play crucial roles in the photocatalysis process, were studied by employing steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra, photocurrent measurements, and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS). Remarkably, the steady-state PL spectrum of Cd­(dcbpy) shows a much lower intensity compared to those of Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) and Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) (c). It suggests the lower probability of the band to band electron–hole recombination for Cd­(dcbpy), corresponding to the more efficient photogenerated charges transfer and separation. As is shown in d, Cd­(dcbpy) presents the highest photocurrent response among the three Cd-MOFs, implying that it has the most efficient electron–hole pairs separation. Moreover, EIS experiment reveals that Cd­(dcbpy) has the smallest radius and lowest resistance among the three Cd-MOFs, which is favorable for the electron transfer in it (). All of the above results support that Cd­(dcbpy) has the best photocatalytic performance for the amine oxidation. The proposed mechanism can be described as follows. Upon light irradiation, the photogenerated electrons (e–) migrate from VB to CB of the catalyst, leaving holes (h+) at HOMO. The benzylamine is oxidized by holes to benzaldehyde, which reacts with benzylamine to generate N-benzylbenzaldimine. The O2 molecules are reduced by e– and combine with H+ to form H2O.
elements.clean_text: Further, the separation efficiency and transfer behavior of photoinduced charges in the photocatalysts, which play crucial roles in the photocatalysis process, were studied by employing steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra, photocurrent measurements, and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS). Remarkably, the steady-state PL spectrum of Cd(dcbpy) shows a much lower intensity compared to those of Cd(bdc)(bpy) and Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) (c). It suggests the lower probability of the band to band electron-hole recombination for Cd(dcbpy), corresponding to the more efficient photogenerated charges transfer and separation. As is shown in d, Cd(dcbpy) presents the highest photocurrent response among the three Cd-MOFs, implying that it has the most efficient electron-hole pairs separation. Moreover, EIS experiment reveals that Cd(dcbpy) has the smallest radius and lowest resistance among the three Cd-MOFs, which is favorable for the electron transfer in it (). All of the above results support that Cd(dcbpy) has the best photocatalytic performance for the amine oxidation. The proposed mechanism can be described as follows. Upon light irradiation, the photogenerated electrons (e-) migrate from VB to CB of the catalyst, leaving holes (h+) at HOMO. The benzylamine is oxidized by holes to benzaldehyde, which reacts with benzylamine to generate N-benzylbenzaldimine. The O2 molecules are reduced by e- and combine with H+ to form H2O.

elements.content: In summary, we synthesized for the first time three bpy-containing Cd-MOFs. The synergistic effect between Cd­(II) ions and light-sensitive bpy-containing ligands endows the Cd-MOFs light-harvesting abilities and suitable photocatalysis energy potentials. Moreover, the high crystallization and continuous 3D structure of Cd­(dcbpy) improve its charge transfer and separation abilities. Owing to these unique features, the as-synthesized bpy-containing Cd-MOFs exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity for the oxidization of benzylamine to N-benzylbenzaldimine under mild conditions, i.e., air atmosphere, room temperature, and the absence of additional photosensitizer or cocatalyst. This work provides new insight into designing and fabricating photocatalytically active MOFs for solar-energy conversion. The highly active and low-cost bpy-containing Cd-MOFs have great potentials in other photochemical reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we synthesized for the first time three bpy-containing Cd-MOFs. The synergistic effect between Cd(II) ions and light-sensitive bpy-containing ligands endows the Cd-MOFs light-harvesting abilities and suitable photocatalysis energy potentials. Moreover, the high crystallization and continuous 3D structure of Cd(dcbpy) improve its charge transfer and separation abilities. Owing to these unique features, the as-synthesized bpy-containing Cd-MOFs exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity for the oxidization of benzylamine to N-benzylbenzaldimine under mild conditions, i.e., air atmosphere, room temperature, and the absence of additional photosensitizer or cocatalyst. This work provides new insight into designing and fabricating photocatalytically active MOFs for solar-energy conversion. The highly active and low-cost bpy-containing Cd-MOFs have great potentials in other photochemical reactions.

elements.content: H2dcbpy (97%) was provided by Ark Pharm, Inc. H2bdc (99%), bpy (98%), 2Me-bpy (98%), mesitylene (TMS, 98%), 4-(trifluoromethoxy)­benzylamine (98%), 4-chlorobenzylamine (97%), 4-methylbenzylamine (98%), 4-methoxybenzylamine (98%), and methyl sulfoxide-d 6 (99.8% D) were purchased from InnoChem Science & Technology Co., Ltd. Cadmium iodide (CdI2, 99.5%) was produced by Aladdin Industrial Corp. Cadmium nitrate tetrahydrate (Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, 98.5%) was produced by Alfa Aesar Corp. DMF (A. R. grade), methyl sulfoxide (DMSO, A. R. grade), and ethanol (A. R. grade) were produced by Beijing Chemical Works. Benzylamine (99%) and TEA (99%) were produced by Acros Organic of Thermo Fisher Scientific Co., Ltd. Mesitylene was purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. All chemicals were used directly without additional purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

H2dcbpy (97%) was provided by Ark Pharm, Inc. H2bdc (99%), bpy (98%), 2Me-bpy (98%), mesitylene (TMS, 98%), 4-(trifluoromethoxy)benzylamine (98%), 4-chlorobenzylamine (97%), 4-methylbenzylamine (98%), 4-methoxybenzylamine (98%), and methyl sulfoxide-d 6 (99.8% D) were purchased from InnoChem Science & Technology Co., Ltd. Cadmium iodide (CdI2, 99.5%) was produced by Aladdin Industrial Corp. Cadmium nitrate tetrahydrate (Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, 98.5%) was produced by Alfa Aesar Corp. DMF (A. R. grade), methyl sulfoxide (DMSO, A. R. grade), and ethanol (A. R. grade) were produced by Beijing Chemical Works. Benzylamine (99%) and TEA (99%) were produced by Acros Organic of Thermo Fisher Scientific Co., Ltd. Mesitylene was purchased from J&K Scientific Ltd. All chemicals were used directly without additional purification.

elements.content: XRD was performed using a Rigaku D/max-2500 200 mA with Cu Kα radiation. FT-IR spectra were recorded over the range of 4000 to 400 cm–1 by using a FT-IR Bruker Tensor-27 spectrometer. The sample was dispersed in KBr discs. TGA was carried out on a TGA 4000 instrument from PerkinElmer.

elements.content: For the synthesis of Cd­(dcbpy) single crystal, 247.8 mg of H2dcbpy was dissolved in 60 mL of DMF/DMSO (v:v = 1:1) mixed solvent. A 308.2 mg amount of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol. Subsequently, they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOF Single Crystals and Characterizations

For the synthesis of Cd(dcbpy) single crystal, 247.8 mg of H2dcbpy was dissolved in 60 mL of DMF/DMSO (v:v = 1:1) mixed solvent. A 308.2 mg amount of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol. Subsequently, they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.

elements.content: For the synthesis of Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) single crystal, 367.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 156.6 mg of 2,2′-bipyridyl, and 165.0 mg H2bdc were dissolved in 12 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.
elements.clean_text: For the synthesis of Cd(bdc)(bpy) single crystal, 367.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 156.6 mg of 2,2'-bipyridyl, and 165.0 mg H2bdc were dissolved in 12 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.

elements.content: For the synthesis of Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) single crystal, 366.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 184.2 mg of 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridyl, and 167.1 mg of H2bdc were dissolved in 8 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.
elements.clean_text: For the synthesis of Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) single crystal, 366.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 184.2 mg of 4,4'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridyl, and 167.1 mg of H2bdc were dissolved in 8 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.

elements.content: Single X-ray diffraction data were collected at 173 K on a Rigaku diffractometer with confused monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a UV-2600 spectrometer within the wavelength range of 220–800 nm, using BaSO4 as a reference. Photoluminescence emission spectra were obtained on an FLS980 fluorescence spectrophotometer with 270 nm excitation at room temperature (Edinburgh Instruments, U.K.). The structure was solved by direct method and refined by full matrix least-squares method on F 2 using SHELX program and Olex2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms.
elements.clean_text: Single X-ray diffraction data were collected at 173 K on a Rigaku diffractometer with confused monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The UV-vis absorption spectra were recorded on a UV-2600 spectrometer within the wavelength range of 220-800 nm, using BaSO4 as a reference. Photoluminescence emission spectra were obtained on an FLS980 fluorescence spectrophotometer with 270 nm excitation at room temperature (Edinburgh Instruments, U.K.). The structure was solved by direct method and refined by full matrix least-squares method on F 2 using SHELX program and Olex2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: Photoelectrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument, Shanghai, China) in a standard three-electrode system with the photocatalyst-coated ITO as the working electrode, graphite electrode (i.d. = 0.4 mm) as the counter electrode, and an Ag/AgCl with 3.5 M KCl as a reference electrode. A 300 W xenon lamp with full spectrum was used as light source. A 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution was used as electrolyte. The Cd-MOF photocatalyst (10 mg) was dispersed into a mixed solution with 20 μL of 5 wt % Nafion and 0.2 mL of ethanol, and the working electrodes were prepared by dropping the suspension (200 μL) onto the surface of an ITO plate with an area of 1.5 cm2.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

Photoelectrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument, Shanghai, China) in a standard three-electrode system with the photocatalyst-coated ITO as the working electrode, graphite electrode (i.d. = 0.4 mm) as the counter electrode, and an Ag/AgCl with 3.5 M KCl as a reference electrode. A 300 W xenon lamp with full spectrum was used as light source. A 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution was used as electrolyte. The Cd-MOF photocatalyst (10 mg) was dispersed into a mixed solution with 20 μL of 5 wt % Nafion and 0.2 mL of ethanol, and the working electrodes were prepared by dropping the suspension (200 μL) onto the surface of an ITO plate with an area of 1.5 cm2.

elements.content: Typically, the Cd-MOF photocatalyst (10 mg) was dispersed in 5 mL of DMF and 0.48 mmol of amine in a 100 mL round-bottom flask with magnetic stirring for 30 min, which was then sealed with a rubber plug and irradiated by a 300 W xenon lamp. After the desired irradiation time, the heterogeneous mixture was centrifuged. The liquid mixture was analyzed by 1H NMR method, which was conducted on a Bruker Avance III 400 HD spectrometer in DMSO-d 6 with TMS as an internal standard ().
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Oxidation of Amine Coupling

Typically, the Cd-MOF photocatalyst (10 mg) was dispersed in 5 mL of DMF and 0.48 mmol of amine in a 100 mL round-bottom flask with magnetic stirring for 30 min, which was then sealed with a rubber plug and irradiated by a 300 W xenon lamp. After the desired irradiation time, the heterogeneous mixture was centrifuged. The liquid mixture was analyzed by 1H NMR method, which was conducted on a Bruker Avance III 400 HD spectrometer in DMSO-d 6 with TMS as an internal standard ().

cln_elements.content:
For the synthesis of Cd­(dcbpy), 244.5 mg of H2dcbpy and 366.0 mg of CdI2 were dissolved in 50 mL of DMF and then added 2 mL of TEA in the system. The solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave, heated at 120 °C for 24 h with stirring, and then cooled to room temperature. The powder was filtered, washed with DMF and ethanol, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h.

For the synthesis of Cd­(bdc)­(bpy), 733.2 mg CdI2, 333.5 mg H2bdc and 312.5 mg 2,2′-bipyridyl were dissolved in 25 mL DMF and then added 2 mL TEA in the system. The solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h with stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless powders was filtered, washed with DMF and ethanol, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h.

For the synthesis of Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy), 734.7 mg of CdI2, 332.9 mg of H2bdc, and 368.3 mg of 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridyl were dissolved in 25 mL of DMF and then 2 mL of TEA was added in the system. The solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h with stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless powders were filtered, washed with DMF and ethanol, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h.

Synthesis of MOF Single Crystals and Characterizations

For the synthesis of Cd­(dcbpy) single crystal, 247.8 mg of H2dcbpy was dissolved in 60 mL of DMF/DMSO (v:v = 1:1) mixed solvent. A 308.2 mg amount of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol. Subsequently, they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.

For the synthesis of Cd­(bdc)­(bpy) single crystal, 367.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 156.6 mg of 2,2′-bipyridyl, and 165.0 mg H2bdc were dissolved in 12 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.

For the synthesis of Cd­(bdc)­(2Me-bpy) single crystal, 366.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 184.2 mg of 4,4′-dimethyl-2,2′-bipyridyl, and 167.1 mg of H2bdc were dissolved in 8 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOF Photocatalysts and Characterizations

For the synthesis of Cd(dcbpy), 244.5 mg of H2dcbpy and 366.0 mg of CdI2 were dissolved in 50 mL of DMF and then added 2 mL of TEA in the system. The solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave, heated at 120 °C for 24 h with stirring, and then cooled to room temperature. The powder was filtered, washed with DMF and ethanol, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h.

For the synthesis of Cd(bdc)(bpy), 733.2 mg CdI2, 333.5 mg H2bdc and 312.5 mg 2,2'-bipyridyl were dissolved in 25 mL DMF and then added 2 mL TEA in the system. The solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h with stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless powders was filtered, washed with DMF and ethanol, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h.

For the synthesis of Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy), 734.7 mg of CdI2, 332.9 mg of H2bdc, and 368.3 mg of 4,4'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridyl were dissolved in 25 mL of DMF and then 2 mL of TEA was added in the system. The solution was sealed in a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h with stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The colorless powders were filtered, washed with DMF and ethanol, and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h.

Synthesis of MOF Single Crystals and Characterizations

For the synthesis of Cd(dcbpy) single crystal, 247.8 mg of H2dcbpy was dissolved in 60 mL of DMF/DMSO (v:v = 1:1) mixed solvent. A 308.2 mg amount of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol. Subsequently, they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.

For the synthesis of Cd(bdc)(bpy) single crystal, 367.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 156.6 mg of 2,2'-bipyridyl, and 165.0 mg H2bdc were dissolved in 12 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.

For the synthesis of Cd(bdc)(2Me-bpy) single crystal, 366.8 mg of CdI2 was dissolved in 4 mL of ethanol, 184.2 mg of 4,4'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridyl, and 167.1 mg of H2bdc were dissolved in 8 mL of DMF. Then they were mixed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask and kept at 120 °C for 2 days without stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the colorless crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with DMF and ethanol, and dried in air under room temperature.
